results.description:
SUBJECTS 14-16

14 Landscape: Zoomed In - Most landscapes are wide sweeping images. Try an alternative and zoom in instead.


15 Artistic: Metal - Cold, hard steel. Shiny Aluminum. Or even rusted and broken down. Find your inspiration in metal.


16 Portrait: Movement- Most portraits are stationary, so explore adding some movement. Dancing, twirling, or even hair flips.


*** Upload 1 or 2 images per subject max.
*** Please try to Caption your work.
*** Please make constructive, appreciative comments on a minimum of 2 other images for every image you post.
*** 1 image from your library can be shared per subject, but the object is to take new images.
*** Images should be uploaded between Apr 1st and May 1st


If anyone has suggestions or an on-line source that would be helpful to a specific subject, please share in the comments for the challenge.

results.description:
April 1, 2016

Learn the Secrets of Social Media Success at the North Shore Business Forum

Julia Campbell, J. Campbell Social Marketing

Digital tools such as websites, blogs, email, and social media platforms have completely changed the marketing landscape for business owners. With the ever-changing nature of social media, getting traction and reaching customers on these platforms can often leave business owners perplexed, confused, and overwhelmed. Local digital marketing expert Julia Campbell of J. Campbell Social Marketing will share the keys to social media success, using examples from small local businesses doing it right.

About the Speaker: Julia Campbell is the owner of J. Campbell Social Marketing in Beverly, MA. She is a Beverly native, a mom of two, a Returned Peace Corps Volunteer, and enthusiast of all things Internet. Her business is all about helping nonprofits and business owners reach more of their supporters and customers, using the powerful tools available via the web. Whether it be social media, email marketing, blogging, or crowdfunding, Julia is able to answer your questions, provide ideas and technical training, and impart advice. For more information, contact Julia at [masked] or visit http://www.jcsocialmarketing.com.

The North Shore Business Forum, Inc. (NSBF) is a group of small business owners from Boston’s North Shore who meet on the first and third Friday of each month for informal lectures given by business owners on a wide variety of topics. Members give a 30-second introduction of their business at each meeting. All business owners are welcome: future, past, profitable, experienced or beginning. Meetings are from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. (registration starts at 7:15) at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. The $10.00 admission fee includes a breakfast buffet. No pre-registration necessary.

Contact: Brett Kirkpatrick, NSBF President,[masked], Email: [masked].
results.name: Learn the Secrets of Social Media Success at the NSBF

results.description:
This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. We'll wait about 15 minutes before starting the walk.  Running really late? You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk.  

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.

Galoop is offering free demo classes in Coolidge Corner, Brookline. Come try a class before the Spring Session starts on April 4th!

 If you have not yet heard what Galoop Classes are all about,  here is a brief description: Galoop's Child Development classes are the perfect fit for babies, toddlers, and preschoolers. Galoop's classes offer the right balance of exploration and structure and provide your child with the ideal environment to learn, create, and have fun.


Each class is an hour long and includes a circle time with songs and parachute play, art and sensory activities, fine and gross motor activities, free play, child development and parenting topics for parents and caregivers, story time, and goodbyes. The songs, activities, discussion topics, and books in Galoop classes are tailored for each age group.

Registration required and space is limited— please register at http://www.galoopclasses.com/class-schedule/

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
MFA First Friday Social Art Evening Museum of Fine Arts (West Wing Information room),Address: 465 Huntington Ave, Boston, MA 02115 tel[masked]


<------

Save wait time in line by entering the rear (Fenway )entrance of the MFA since the front gets busy.

<---------

ORGANIZER: Jimmy will be at one of the back tables at the MFA Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All Members of ALL AGES that like Art and a relaxed social atmosphere!

Admission: $25 per person -- Free for MFA Members. ...If you are an MFA members please try to arrange through comments to help get other members of our group in as your guest for free. You can also try to get a discount pass at your local library get you in for free or $10 a Person. Hey we all need to save a few bucks for drink later right?

Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM. After that try to find us in the Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard its where the party is at. and it the big tall room with the huge green glass Chihuly art piece is in. Stay as long as you want. MFA First Fridays ends at 9PM the Museum closed at 9:45PM.

MFA First Fridays is on the first Friday of each month from 6:00–9:30 pm. Join us for fine art, music, cash bars featuring signature cocktails, and delicious tapas available for purchase. Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

Accepted forms of identification for First Friday entrance include:
Massachusetts Drivers License
Massachusetts Liquor ID
Massachusetts ID issued by the Massachusetts Registry of Motor Vehicles
Drivers License from any US state
Valid Passport (photocopies are not accepted)
Federal Identification (e.g. Military ID)

We can mix and mingle with fellow art lovers,  enjoy the art,  the music and sip on our lovely drinks. hen we can break off and look at some more art since the rest of the museum is open!

Hope you can make it out this fine Friday Evening out for some Art Culture and great conversations.

======================================================

Notes for Parking for the MFA: It will be busy and lots tend to fill up fast so try to get there early! Taking the T is your best bet!

Self Parking Options: Visitors to the MFA have three self-parking options: the Huntington Lot, the Fenway Lot, and the Museum Road Garage, all of which have entrances on Museum Road. The Huntington lot offers closer parking to the Huntington Avenue Entrance and the Fenway parking lot is more accessible to the State Street Corporation Fenway Entrance. MFA lost Park costs $$$ over $20 so be prepared.

Subway Take the Green Line E train to the Museum of Fine Arts stop, or the Orange Line train to the Ruggles stop.
results.how_to_find_us: Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM.

ART, MUSIC, DANCING

Let's meet out in the lobby in front at the main entrance at 6pm. near the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus (3 headed dog). Then we will head in at 6:10 to make sure we get in. We will congregate and get some tables to the left near the big cube with the poster, which has the stairs and the elevator behind it.

Try not to be late, as it fills up quickly and then they stop letting people in. I am BIll, 6'4".

The cost of museum entry is $25, but if people  have dual memberships they can get others in for free, so if you have a dual let us know via meetup comments, or RSVP comment.

I will usually email my phone # before the event to attendees so if you miss us in the foyer you can call or text (preferred) if you can't find us when/if you get in.   Look at everyone's pictures so we know who is going.  I will try to bring a copy of the pictures and will keep an eye out to say hi & introduce people.

BE SURE TO GET THERE EARLY, AS THE PLACE FILLS UP AND THEY TURN PEOPLE AWAY.  You need a license or Mass ID to enter.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.

results.description:
</a>

ONE Cantonese Event each Friday evening - with SEVERAL ACCOMPLISHED Cantonese speakers/teachers/guides - at the Huntington Avenue YMCA/Hastings Hall - Room # 101

The ONLY entrance is at 320 Huntington Avenue.

The weekly Cantonese-English chat begins with a one-hour level 1 Cantonese language class followed by a free chat. 

<a href="https://www.google.com/maps/dir/">https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until mid-April, Dandan's YMCA-based Cantonese-English class and chat will be in in Boston YMCA 101.

Dandan 'Danni' Mai and Xiao 'Cecelia' Xiu, from the PRC (and NEU), host these friendly meetups (in Boston YMCA 101), and Frankie Presta may also instruct.

* Cantonese speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?  
* English speakers want to learn Cantonese?  
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Cantonese?

Schedule: 
6:00 - 7:00PM - Cantonese class 
7:00 - 9:00PM - Bilingual free chat.

6:00 - 7:00 - 廣東話班
7:00 - 9:00 - 雙語談話

* Green Line E-Line comes above ground to Northeastern, and the YMCA is around the corner.
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, walking through Northeastern University.
* Walking from Brookline is about 15 minutes.
* MFA, Wentworth, College, and Harvard's LMA are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue. 
* Route 9 comes near the area, via Brookline.
* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find).

New England Conservatory (NEU) is on the corner, followed by The Huntington Avenue YMCA, and then the entrance to Hasting fall is at the end of that block at 320 Huntington Avenue.  This building is OWNED BY NEU.

By MBTA, get off at 

• Northeastern University stop on Huntington Avenue E-Line (MBTA Green E) 
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on the Orange Line (then walk around NEC to YMCA).
• New England Conservatory stop on #39 bus
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on #1 bus from Harvard Square (then walk around NEC to YMCA).

results.description:
Join MassCEC for the upcoming 5th Annual Boston Cleanweb Hackathon, taking place at LogMeIn from April 1st to April 3rd 2016. Whether you are an coder, industry expert, web developer, innovator, student or an established member of the Cleanweb community, all are welcome to participate in this weekend long technology competition!

In teams, participants will compete for cash prizes in an effort to create a user friendly web or app based platform that will help consumers and businesses use energy and natural resources more efficiently. The event kicks off with a team formation mixer and challenge presentations on Friday, April 1st and then coding begins in the morning on Saturday, April 2nd. Participants have 30 hours create an application that addresses energy, waste, water, transportation, food or other energy and sustainability issues. We wrap up on Sunday afternoon with pitches to a panel of judges and awards. Lots of food and coffee will be provided.

Don't forget to sign up on our Eventbrite Page! An email will be sent when the link goes live.
results.name: MassCEC 5th Annual Boston Cleanweb Hackathon

results.description:
The Museum of Fine Arts is open from 6PM to 9:30PM on first Fridays. The entire museum is open. In the Shapiro Courtyard (the indoor courtyard with the Chihuly green glass Christmas Tree and the restaurant) the MFA sets up a cash bar and a DJ. From 6PM its mostly at 40-60 set to talk. After about 7PM the volume of the music goes up, the 25-35 year olds arrive, and the event shifts from talk to dancing. The place often fills up a bit after 7, so don’t be later than that.

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/mfa-first-fridays

Museum admission and event ticketing. The event is free with museum admission, either for members or general admission ($25, $23 for seniors), either at the door or online at http://www.mfa.org/visit. Many local libraries sell discounted tickets, for example two tickets for $10. Also, many employers may have discounted or even free tickets for their employees, check your human resources department.

First Friday is separately ticketed (at no additional charge), even if you are a member or preticketed.  You need to go through the admission line to get a separate ticket.  The line is tolerable at 6:00PM, and way way bad at 6:10.

If people have dual memberships they can get others in for free. As we gather at the front lobby, we can figure out any ticket sharing arrangements.

Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

It's not complicated.  Just show up and find one or another of the Meetup groups.  Someone will point you to the right lines to stand in, and maybe share a ticket.


Transportation. Public transportation strongly recommended, parking is a pain. The Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Directions by every transportation mode at http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

Meeting up with others—how to find us. The Fine Culture in Boston and Culture Vultures groups meet in the Huntington Avenue main entrance lobby at 6PM near the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus (3 headed dog). Then we will head in at 6:10.

If you arrive later, as you enter the courtyard, look to your left, and meet us at the tables near the elevator station with the poster of the current show.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

After. The event closes at 9:30.  We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.
results.name: MFA First Friday—Conversation, Art, Music, Dancing

group.name: Fine Culture in Boston (and International Travel)

results.description:
Onward we go to the Field Trip & Sip!  RAIN OR RAIN!  Join us!

Meet for thrifting at Global Thrift OR meet us after for the SIP at Bistro 781, which is just a few doors down, FREE PARKING. 

Let's meet for a "power hour" (or so) of exploration at Global Thrift and then make our way to Bistro 781, (bistro781.com) which is very close by--for "sip" and a nosh of something great.  

Global Thrift, is open till 8PM on Fridays, and like most thrift stores is completely "hit or miss" when it comes to fabulous finds...it's quirky, can be a bit dusty, perhaps jumbled or musty, though always evolving and colorful people abound!  There are dressing rooms and the young staff there is super helpful.  Let's see what we can find!

There is FREE parking for Global (and Bistro 781) behind the building--and metered parking in Waltham, runs until 6 on the street and local lots.   Bistro 781 is upscale American cuisine with cocktails and craft beers, featuring gluten free, vegan and vegetarian dishes as well.  

Hope to see some of you there, and please, RSVP accordingly AND please join us at Bistro 781 at 730 if you just want to hang out and meet for a drink!  Suggestions and feedback is always welcome!
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet inside the back door entrance (free parking behind building for both places!)
results.name: Even in the RAIN! Field Trip & Sip at GLOBAL THRIFT WALTHAM and BISTRO 781!

In term of the attunement results, it is not the same as Reiki Tummo attunement because the Usui Reiki attunements will only open upper half of your main energy channel/sushumna (from crown chakra to heart chakra) while Reiki Tummo attunements will open the whole sushumna from crown chakra up to base chakra. However, this free Usui Reiki Level 1 attunement is given remotely by Mr. Irmansyah Effendi by means of Reiki Tummo attunement techniques, so the result is somehow better than traditional Usui Reiki attunement results.

Since it is given by means of Reiki Tummo attunement technique, the result is very good for cleansing your crown chakra, heart chakra as well as palm chakras and energy channels. All alumni of Reiki Tummo workshops from Padmacahaya or Padmajaya are entitled to join and receive this free mass attunement as Reiki Tummo attunement (because you already received one before). 

Please read the instruction below on DISTANT ATTUNEMENT PREPARATION. Also since the main benefit of the attunement is to help your heart get better connection to Divine Love and Light so your heart can be opened and cleansed better by Divine Love and Light then we suggest you to also do OPEN HEART PRAYER/MEDITATION daily before and after the attunement. Please read more information below. 

May you enjoy and get benefit from this mass attunement. 

Much Love and Light for your beautiful hearts, :) 

----------------------------------------------------------
DISTANT ATTUNEMENT PREPARATION
Note: No need to register in advance, just be ready during the attunement.

WHAT TO DO FOR A DISTANT ATTUNEMENT

1. You do not need to register to receive this free mass attunement of Usui Reiki Level 1. Just prepare your self at the day of the attunement (1st of each month) 
2. No need to adjust your local time any longer. The attunement has been programmed to be received every 1st of each month at 6.30 PM YOUR OWN LOCAL TIME, where ever you are, for 15 minutes duration. 
3. Please study how to do Self Healing/Treatment with Reiki. You can find this in some web pages or in some Reiki books. You do need to do self healing right away after the attunement is finished to make good use of the attunement energy flow that is still working on you even though the attunement is over already. Please see Note below for suggested hand positions during self healing. 
4. On the attunement day, try to get a room where you will not be disturbed. The attunement will take about 15 minutes. It is best to have a room in which the light is not too bright. If possible, have new age music and incense or aroma therapy ready. Dim light and music will help you to get relaxed easily. The incense or aroma therapy will be needed to neutralize the negative energy that will come out of you during the attunement. Remember the attunement is also a cleansing process. 
5. About 30 minutes before the attunement, it is good to start doing simple and light exercises that move most parts of your body, but don't make yourself exhausted. Simply do exercise for about 30-60 seconds for each part of the body. This will help energy flow even better in your physical body layer. 
6. Since the attunement will help opening your heart connection to Divine energy, then for better result, we suggest you to do Open Heart Prayer/Meditation after doing simple exercises. That can be done about 15 minutes before the attunement. Please read more information on Open Heart Prayer/Meditation below. 
7. After the simple exercises and Open Heart Prayer, get relaxed, dim the light, and turn the music on. Light incense before the attunement starts. Sit on a chair; try to keep your spine straight without forcing it. Make sure that your legs are not crossed and it is better if both feet are grounded. Put both of your hands on your thighs with your palms facing upwards. Please don't fall asleep during the attunement! :) 
8. During the attunement, simply relax. Do not make any effort to concentrate. Do not practice any breathing technique. Try to be as still as possible and enjoy whatever happens. It is a good practice to always relaxed, smile at your heart and surrender to Divine Source of Love and Light during the attunement. Also be willing to open your heart to Divine Source to receive more Divine Love and Light during the attunement. It is all done by intention only and then relaxed, smile and enjoy the attunement process. DO NOT EXPECT anything to happen since this will make you are not relaxed anymore :) 
9. After the attunement, do a complete self-healing directly. Take your time and do it properly and enjoy with smile and happy feeling from your heart all the time. 
10. After self-healing, try to do the same simple exercises you did before the attunement to help your physical body absorb Reiki energy better.
11. Keep on doing self healing for at least 21 days. It is best to do it every day even after you pass the 21-days period to maintain your health and improve your energy. Also, since the main benefit of channeling Reiki energy is to open and cleanse our heart, then it is always better to do Open Heart Prayer also every day to cleanse and keep our heart open better for Divine Love and Light.

Note: 
1) Suggested hand positions for channeling Reiki energy during Self Healing are (3 minutes per position sequentially): 
FRONT OF THE BODY: Forehead/face, Cheeks, Throat, Upper chest, Lower chest, Stomach, Thighs, Knees, and Ankles
BACK OF THE BODY: Back of the head, Nape of the neck, Upper back, Lower back/waist, Buttocks, Back of thighs, Calves and Soles of the feet 
2) More detail and complete techniques about doing healing and other Reiki techniques will be taught in Reiki Tummo workshops. Visit www.padmacahaya.com or www.padmacahaya.org for more information.
3) Please feel free to share your experiences after the attunement and doing Self Healing for 21 days and Open Heart Meditation every day.

----------------------------------------------------------
OPEN HEART PRAYER/MEDITATION
(By Irmansyah Effendi)

Each time we have negative emotion, we leave / deposit negativities within our heart. How many time a day we have negative emotions, even though we do not show them. To cleanse the heart further (bigger and deeper), the best way is to ask for blessing from the True Source of Love and Light. 

Before you start this prayer, you may need to write down the name of the people you don't like (you need to forgive), and for what you need to ask for forgiveness. You can replace the terminology “True Source” with any other terminology which you are more comfortable with / can relate better to.

STEPS:
(Follow your feeling while praying)
1. Touch your heart (center of your chest) with 1 or 2 fingers
2. Close your eyes
3. Relax
4. Smile
5. Smile to your heart sweetly and freely
6. Feel the nice feeling from your heart, smile and stay within that nice feeling along the prayer
7. Pray (from the heart with feeling and love): 
1) True Source, please bless our heart so that all arrogance be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
2) True Source, please bless our heart so that all selfishness be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
3) True Source, please bless our heart so that all anger be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
4) True Source, please bless our heart so that all envy and jealousy be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
5) True Source, please bless our heart so that all greediness and cunningness be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
6) True Source, please bless our heart to understand that peace, calmness and joy are better than negative emotions. We have to let go of all negative emotions toward others, so that You can bless our heart, to fill our heart with Your Love and Light, peace, calmness and joy. Please bless and help us to be able to forgive everyone sincerely.
{Now, forgive everyone sincerely, although the same person has been doing the same negative things repeatedly and is still doing it. Remember that keeping negative emotion in you will simply give you pressure and burdens.}
7) True Source, as we have forgiven everyone else, please bless our heart so that all hatred, sadness, resentment, disappointment and other negative emotions, be removed to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
8) True Source, please bless and help us to realize that You are All Loving and All Forgiving. Please bless and help us to realize all of our mistakes, be remorseful, and ask for forgiveness. 
{Now, realize all of your mistakes, be remorseful, and ask for forgiveness.}
9) True Source, as You have forgiven all of our mistakes, please bless our heart and whole being so that all fear, worry, and burdens because of those mistakes, be removed to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
10) True Source, please bless and help us to be able to stay within our heart, within Your Love and Light, to always be peaceful, calm, and joyful.
11) True Source, thank You for all of Your blessing, Love and Light.
12) Amen.

Note:
a. Since the most important benefit of Reiki attunement for our heart is to open and connecting our heart better to Divine Love and Light to cleanse our heart further, so for better results of Reiki attunement on your self and heart, it is suggested to do this Open Heart Prayer prior to receiving the attunement (say starting 2 weeks daily before the attunement) and every day after the attunement. 
b. The Open Heart Prayer CD in English or Indonesian language is available for purchase. 
c. More techniques and practice on opening and activating your heart can be learnt through Open Heart Workshop from Padmacahaya. For more information on Open Heart Workshop please visit http://openheartworkshops.com

The protagonist lives a happy life which he discovers is actually the focus of a reality TV show aired since his birth. He is the star, his hometown is a giant set piece, and everyone around him is an actor going by a script! What happens when he finds out his reality is a TV Show?

The film was nominated for several Oscars and won three Golden Globe Awards.

The Critics Consensus on Rotten Tomatoes:  A funny, tender, and thought-provoking film…all the more noteworthy for its remarkably prescient vision of runaway celebrity culture and a nation with an insatiable thirst for the private details of ordinary lives.  94% Tomatometer

About this Group: We meet monthly to look at popular films through the lens of spirituality/faith. All are welcome to join the screening of a recent film followed by a discussion led by a local theologian. BYOBeer, Wine and Soda.


Screening and Discussion led by Rev. Anastasia Kidd and/or Rev. Chad Kidd; A Free Will Offering will be collected; suggested donation of 10.00 per person..


6:30 pm doors open; 6:45 Screening; 8:45 - 9:30 Discussion

We provide High Definition films on a large screen, comfortable seating, light snacks and a great discussion leader!

Call[masked] or email [masked] to find out the film title and to get on our mailing list for details about our monthly Faith and Film events as well as our other Arts and Inspiration programs (music, art gallery, and the spoken word).

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.

results.description:
Even from the grave, Plato continues to challenge and influence our philosophical ideas. How much more would he contribute if he were actually among us? In her book, Plato at the Googleplex: Why Philosophy Won’t Go Away, Rebecca Newberger Goldstein inserts Plato into 21st-century America, to go on a book tour for his Republic. Her account of what he would say at locations ranging from Google headquarters to a talk show modeled on The O’Reilly Factor is by turns hilarious and deeply moving.


He considers all the big questions: What makes life worth living? How should we balance the rights of the individual with the goals of society? Will technology improve or degrade the human condition? Most of all, in light of the tremendous advances in the hard sciences, do the speculations of philosophy even matter anymore?


In this first meeting of the study group, we will become acquainted with the themes of Plato at the Googleplex as we discuss the Prologue. The schedule and pace from there will be as determined by those who attend. Feel free to come to this meeting without having read the book, just to see if it would interest you, but your enjoyment of future meetings will be enhanced if you read the scheduled chapters ahead of time.

**************************************** 


ADMISSION FEE: Bronze and Gold Members are admitted free. Basic members and guests are required to pay a $5.50 admission fee, which is due on or before Friday, March 25th. PLEASE PAY HERE. Any unpaid registration (RSVP) as of March 26th will be changed to "not attending." Afterwards, you may re-register your RSVP to “Yes, attending” but you must first process your payment.


Bronze Membership entitles you to attend great events such as Impromptu Philosophizers, study group meetings and more! Instead of paying the admission fee, you can purchase a Bronze Membership for only $15 per year. To purchase a Bronze Membership, please visit the Membership Page .
results.name: Plato at the Googleplex Study Group: Inaugural Meeting

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

At the heart of any live set is the mixer, with everything else either flowing into or out of this central hub. It’s where all the sound is collected to be fit together before going out to the ears of the audience, the last line of defense for the Artist so to speak. So how can you go about using one in your live performances? This week we’ll be analyzing the signal flow of analog mixers, and exploring performance techniques using a multichannel mixing board, drum machines, and synthesizers.

Damian Silva is co­founder and creative director of Bassic, Boston’s first and longest running Dubstep night. He has been DJing since 1997 when he was first exposed to the sounds of Jungle/Drum & Bass in Philly’s early rave scene. In that time he has started 2 promotion companies, managed a nightclub, established 2 long running monthly nights and performed at dozens of events.
results.name: Inside Performing w/ an Analog Mixing Board [4/1] #FREE

results.description:
Join us for an evening of fun and connection as we play 3 communication games where we get the opportunity to say the truth and be real with each other (no touching and no one takes off any clothes). Add chocolate (yes please!) and you're off to a great start to your evening!


Imagine meeting new people in an environment where everyone feels comfortable to be themselves. It’s a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation—a place where everyone gets to say the truth. Through other people putting quality attention on you, and asking you questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening—really listening—to your responses, you have the opportunity to examine yourself. It’s a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good, which allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

You can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you. You don't have to do anything you don't want to, or answer any questions you don't want to answer. The games are designed to create the sensations in your body that you might have during Orgasmic Meditation* without having to actually do the practice—just through talking. What comes up might surprise you.

Even in a room full of strangers, it's amazing how connected we can end up feeling when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston. *At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation which class or private training you can take with our masterful teachers and coaches, and what we have to offer so you can have more connection, authenticity, and play in your life!

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time—we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square or Alewife station.

Nicole Daedone (founder of Orgasmic Meditation) on the science of OM:

I am honored and privileged to both:

• Facilitate this healing and awakening journey for individuals and couples in my private practice, and

• Be the Boston Organizer for Tantra The Art of Conscious Loving Beginner Weekend Seminar with Tantra Master Charles Muir in Boston, MA April 29 - May 1, 2016

This evening workshop will be an introduction to the principles and methods of this body of work. I will share some of my personal experiences with you and guide you in some embodiment practices and beautiful connection exercises. You will get a sense of what to expect in the Weekend Seminar or in private sessions.

All are welcome! No partner needed; all levels of experience; all genders and sexual orientations; both singles and couples. No nudity or sexual activity in class. 

Fee: $35; Early Bird: $25 by 3/30

We expect this multi-MeetUp event to sell out, so be sure to secure your spot via eventbrite! (RSVPs on MeetUp do not reflect accurate registration numbers, nor do they secure your spot.)

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
Here's a nice offer from from member Mary MacDonald. This is currently NOT a meetup. YOU CAN make it one by being host. (I'm unable to attend)

Hi Joe, The Cantata Singers are delighted to offer discounted tickets to its performance of Brahm's A German Requiem, this Friday at 8:00 pm at NEC's Jordan Hall. Brahms’ emotional German Requiem is uniquely paired with J.S. Bach’s Cantata BWV 60, “O Ewigkeit, du Donnerwort” and Ricercar, and Anton Webern’s Five Movements for String Orchestra. Webern’s refracted take on Bach, and one of Bach’s most emotionally affecting cantatas beautifully paves the way for Brahms’ radiant music. Soloists include local favorites Majie Zeller, soprano, Lynn Torgove, alto, Eric Christopher Perry, tenor, Mark Andrew Cleveland, bass, and Dana Whiteside, bass. John Harbison, composer and former Cantata Singers’ 

Music Director, will give the pre-concert talk, free to all ticketholders, at 7pm in Williams Hall. 

Following the performance, all are welcome at a free post-concert reception in Williams Hall. 

Meetup Members are entitled to a 20% ticket discount at any level with the promo code "Meetup 1516" when purchasing tickets at https://cantatasingers.secure.force.com/ticket­ Hope you all can join us!
results.name: Cantata Singers: Brahm's A German Requiem,  (ticket offer, not a meetup)

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet 15 minutes before the scheduled time and to the right of the line in front of the Astronomy building on the roof of the Museum of Science to be with the group. The Meetup group will wait for 10 minutes and then get in line.

Influenced by Dr. Lonnie Smith, The Meters, Booker T. and the MGs, Jimmy Smith, Jimmy McGriff, Jack McDuff, Billy Preston, The Beatles, and Rusty Bryant to name a few this is about a movin', groovin' good time out! The band is Johnny Trama - guitar, Rusty Scott - hammond B3 organ, and Dave Brophy - drums.

SARAH AND THE WILD VERSATILE are a fresh addition to the Boston music scene; teaming their long-standing performance experience and wide range of musical expertise with unique instrumental ingenuity and lyrical prowess. Ranging from blues to synth rock, folk to soul, and most anything in between, Sarah and the Wild Versatile have been taking the Boston Music scene by storm; performing with Grammy award winner Booker T. Jones, Nick Moss Band, Danny Bedrosians Secret Army featuring members of Parliament Funkadelic, Sister Sparrow and the Dirty Birds, Jesse Dee, Ruby Rose Fox, and many others."

Tickets ($11) and more info can be found here:
http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2526670

Lizard Lounge is one of my favorite venues to catch live music, due to its intimate setting. It's like the band is playing in your basement. Plus, I've heard B3 Kings before and have not been disappointed. Should be a good show...

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike three of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Bond, Bondcliff, and West Bond. I am planning trips in February, March (will also include Zealand), and April (will also include Hale and Zealand) so I'm going to do each hike using a different route. Here are the details for each of the three events:

• February - Bondcliff, Bond, and West Bond as an out and back from Lincoln Woods. This one will get you three 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 4,200 feet of climbing. It will take about 12 hours 30 minutes to complete. (this will be a "winter" hike)


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265


• March - Zealand, West Bond, Bond, and Bondcliff traverse from Zealand Road to Lincoln Woods. This one will get you four 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 4,000 feet of climbing. It will take about 12 hours 30 minutes to complete. (this will be a "winter" hike)


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/31-Mt-Zealand-4260

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265

• April - Hale, Zealand, West Bond, Bond, and Bondcliff traverse from Fire Warden Trail up Hale to Lincoln Woods. This one will get you five 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 5,300 feet of climbing. It will take about 13 hours 15 minutes to complete. (this will be a "spring" hike)

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/37-Mt-Hale-4054


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/31-Mt-Zealand-4260

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.16811703400049&lon=-71.53396885799964&site=all&smap=1#.VpccTjblweJ


=== What to Bring ===


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Lincoln Woods Visitors Center which is located on the north side of Route 112 east of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 135 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 10 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will end the day we will leave a few cars there and drive to the starting spot.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• </a>https://goo.gl/maps/fnmNxuEiKxm

<a href="https://goo.gl/maps/NhpBuQBan5R2">

results.description:
4月2日早晨将在哈佛公共卫生学院Kresge楼G1举办“中国清洁空气论坛”。这次活动将有领域著名专家就空气污染这一人们关注的话题进行深入讨论。本次讨论将聚焦如下问题：空气污染的危害，室内空气污染的危害，空气污染科学研究和立法，空气污染和能源结构经济发展模式之间的关系，医疗保健体系如何应对空气污染。主讲人包括“哈佛六城市研究”的负责人，这是世界上最早系统证明细颗粒物健康危害的研究；当年推动美国环保署立法禁止含铅汽油的科学家；以及来自哈佛公共卫生学院，肯尼迪学院，中国国家气候中心的学者。公共卫生学院中国学生学者联合会欢迎大家前来关注这一话题。有早餐提供。

The  "China Clean Air Forum" will be held in the morning on April 2 at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, in the Kresge Building, G1 (Snyder Auditorium - the large autitorium in the basement). 

In light of the Six Cities study of 22 years ago, what should China do about risks posed to its population from its air pollution ! What should US cities do?

* http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/features/six-cities-air-pollution-study-turns-20/

* http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199312093292401 - Air Pollution and Mortality in six (6) US cities.

This English-language event will feature well-known experts in the related fields and offer in-depth discussions on the subject of air pollution, specifically in China. 

The morning's discussion will focus on issues pertinent to China (and to other developing nations, and thus to global economic, social, and political development):
the relationship between air pollution hazards, health hazards in general, air pollution research and legislation, air pollution and energy, and developing an economic development model of indoor air pollution that harmonizes political structures, healthcare systems, how to deal preventively and retroactively with air pollution. 

Morning speakers include speakers from the "Harvard Six Cities Study," including Dr. Douglas W. Dockery, the person in charge>>

The Harvard Six Cities Study of the world's urban cities first proved that fine particulate matter is a health hazard.  Maynard's Mission Hill community health group has partnered with HCSPH's environmental health department to conduct a similar study in Mission Hill.  

then push the United States legislation EnvironmentalProtection Agency ban leaded gasoline scientists; and from the Harvard School of Public Health, the Kennedy School China's national climate Center scholar. Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars School of Public Health welcome everyone to pay attention to this topic. 

A compliomentary breakfast will be provided to registrants - to those who have registered before the morning of April 2nd.
results.name: China Clean Air Forum

This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

results.description:
It's easy to make great portraits when your subject is a model like this: 

WHAT's it about?

But what do you do when faced with a regular person who wants you to make them look good? You're right about it often being  a challenge.  Be that as it may, there are many ways to overcome that challenge and lots of tips and tricks you can employ to make your subject  look fantastic! 

From basic posing techniques to simple lighting techniques that you can employ to  literally transform anyone into a good looking portrait subject, this one day workshop has lots to teach you. 

SCHEDULE

The session will be in two parts: 

9am -10am    Introduction to techniques and posing 

10am -12pm  Hands on Model Shoot with natural light 

12pm-1pm     Lunch

1pm -3pm      Advanced posing techniques and lighting set-ups 

3pm - 3.15    Refreshment Break 

3-15 - 4.30   Hands-on shoot.

4.30-6pm     Review of students work and basic post-processing. 

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

The workshop will be held in the spacious studios in Pembroke and to ensure a good experience for everyone there will be a strict limit on numbers. 

The cost is $149 for the day. 

This workshop requires that you have a knowledge and familiarity with setting your camera in manual mode to operate with specific ISO, Aperture and Shutter speed settings.  Many of the lighting setups will involve the use of Speedlight external flashes and you are welcome to bring your own (one can be provided if you don't have one). 

Phottix radio triggers and lighting gear will be provided and adaptors for Sony Cameras can also be provided.

results.description:
Are you curious what a Toastmasters meetup is like?  Want to  improve your public speaking skills, but don't know where to start?

Join us for our spring Open House on April 2.  Toastmasters teaches public speaking through a set of speech projects that highlight specific techniques. We build leadership skills by sharing the roles of running each meeting and by providing feedback and encouragement to one another.  We sneak in some networking too: the Watertown Saturday Toastmasters club is a friendly bunch from a variety of backgrounds and professions. 

Our Open House is a regular meeting followed by a potluck and socializing. 

Guests are welcome at every meeting.  If you can't join us this time, we hope to meet you another time. 


=============================

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.


• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]


Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

Welcome all to the First Watertown Saturday club.

Toastmaster's Welcome 

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches


Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction


Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations


Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks 

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

10:45 AM - 11:15 AM Open House

Enjoy coffee and snacks with us after the meeting. 

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org
results.how_to_find_us: Park on Russell Avenue and enter Church of the Good Shepherd from Russell Avenue. When you enter, walk downstairs and take a left.
results.name: OPEN HOUSE: Watertown Saturday Toastmasters club meeting

results.description:
From Max Tegmark:

"I’m writing to invite you to an awesome 1-day conference at MIT Saturday April 2 about the new trillion dollar nuclear arms race and how we can stop it. Although the over 7,000 US nuclear weapons are way more than enough to deter an enemy attack, the US plans to rekindle the cold war by upgrading them, wasting 4 million of your tax dollars every hour for the next 30 years on something that will make us less safe. What would you rather spend that money on? There’s a wonderful opportunity to put this money to better use, since this obsolete cold-war boondoggle will only continue for as long as most people aren’t aware of it.

This MIT conference brings together a who’s who of researchers and thought-leaders (including former Secretary of Defense William Perry, Cambridge Mayor Denise Simmons, physics Nobel Laureate Frank Wilczek and MIT’s Vice President Maria Zuber) with inspiring students from MIT, Harvard and other universities to brainstorm about how to best turn things around and to tackle fascinating questions. What social media and novel web tools should we build to shine light on this lethal trillion dollar boondoggle and propel it into the public debate ahead of the US election? Is accidental nuclear war a greater risk than nuclear terrorism? What’s the best way to stop the endless string of near-misses that have come close to triggering accidental nuclear war? What does the latest climate science have to say about nuclear winter, whereby smoke from a nuclear war could potentially trigger a mini ice age killing most people on Earth even if the attacked superpower never retaliates? Can we engage the climate change movement in nuclear disarmament because nuclear winter is climate change on steroids? Does the rise of AI increase the risk of nuclear cyberattack and missile-jacking? Please come join this fascinating conversation and help make a difference at what will be one of the most fascinating and important conferences of the year! MIT is the perfect place for this thanks to the long legacy of nuclear disarmament work by MIT faculty including Vicki Weisskopf, Philip Morrison, Herman Feshbach, Randall Forsberg, Bernard Feld, Henry Kendall, Kosta Tsipis, Aron Bernstein, Jonathan King and George Rathjens.


Thanks to MIT-Radius and FLI sponsorship, the conference includes free lunch and the registration is free. I expect it to sell out soon, so if you’d like to join, please register today and share this invitation with interested friends."
results.how_to_find_us: Please register at the conference website.
results.name: MIT conference on reducing nuclear risk

results.description:
Greetings everybody! Today, have an interesting event which I hope will catch your attention!

Comicazi, one of our primary venues, is expanding! They have taken over space adjacent to their location, and will soon be working towards integrating it into their current floor. In the meantime, they are using that space to feature a Yard Sale Event. Ten tables will be available for people who are looking to clear out their collections to make room for newer material.

Why is this going up as an event? Because our group has reserved a table!

If you have stuff you would like to get rid of, especially after the dealers room of Anime Boston, we are offering two options.

First, if you would like to participate as a vendor, you may come, sell your wares, and pay part of the table rental fee ($15 per table divided by the number of vendors). You would then keep any resulting funds, but would be responsible for both managing your things and removing them after the sale ends.

Second, if you would just like to clear out your shelves or media collections, you can arrange to drop off those materials to the group, and any funds raised, minus the table rental fee, would be donated to the group, and any leftover items would be used as a part of the raffle later that night during our Patema Inverted Viewing.

If either of these interests you, please message me directly for details and guidelines. Space is limited, and while we can try to grab a second table, they do tend to go very quickly. So time is of the essence.

Now, this event is open to anyone in Davis Square, not just our membership. In addition, it will be inside, so weather will not be a problem. So, this is a great opportunity to get a lot of exposure and clear out some space at the same time. Hope to see you there!
results.name: Special Event! Comicazi Yard Sale!

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

Join us on April 2, 2016 at the Copley Square Library for a discussion on common questions about the Bible, God, the Christian life, life's injustices, and other questions you may have to consider alongside your consideration of the Bible's answers.  Each hour's presentation focuses on a particular question:

10 AM - With so many things to worry about, is it possible to find peace?

11 AM - I'm fine with God and Jesus, and I'm a pretty good person.  Isn't that enough?

     12 NOON - Break to nearby restaurants, or stick around for more discussion!  Come back for the afternoon's presentations.

1 PM - What should I do? I just don't think I can live the Christian life.

2 PM - Why me? Why am I suffering?

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Mar 5, 12, 19, Apr 2, 9 and 16.  There is no class on the weekend of Mar 26) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
Harvard Iranian Weekend (conference)

Open to the Public. Event link HERE. Register HERE. 

April 2nd & 3rd at the Harvard Science Center, 1 Oxford Street


:: :: ::


Harvard Iranian Weekend (HIW) is a global conference that will convene students, academics, and professionals with an interest in better understanding Iran and Iranian culture, showcasing perspectives and insights on topics of interest including policy, business, technology, and the arts. Taking place April 2-3, 2016, the inaugural HIW theme – “Dialogue” – reflects our belief that open discussion is critical to developing the mutual understanding necessary to overcome many of the current challenges involving Iran and the Iranian community. HIW will provide an open forum for the discussion of diverse issues such as Iran’s role and impact in the international arena, the political and economic challenges involving Iran, the role and impact of Iranian Americans in the United States, and the trajectory of Iranian culture within and outside Iran.
results.name: Harvard Iranian Weekend (2-day conference)

results.description:
Dear Thinkers,

In the first meeting we began to understand how the human mind works.  Boutons ideate.  Boutons, pre-synaptic buttons, sense and link ideas into desirable cognitive sets.  That set of linked ideas is your current mindset.

In this meet-up we will (1) review and (2) advance this concept and method.  Then we will (3) practically apply that meta-knowledge to an important thinking-problem, selected by the group.

The majority of the meetup will focus on Thought Articulation.  This is the practical method for organizing and remembering the ideas needed to be more successful, in any domain of inquiry.  

Thought Articulation in sum: draw a border around a subject, say primary education, selling more, and/or getting elected; and then establish the metric.  That defines the before ideological state.  Then identify and organize the ideas that detail exemplary performance.  Write this or remember it; it's a network of ideas.  When you find yourself in that situation Judge then Do (JAD), based on your current intentions.

If you know how your mind works, sensing and processing information towards a stated objective, then you can take conscious action to make it work better. Our meet-up is for people whom want to apply these new Cognitive Scientific insights, to get smarter.  


Meetup Location: North Shore Community Campus, Lynn Campus.  Meetup is Saturday April 2 at 12 noon to 1:30 PM.  Space for 36 people.  

There are no CogSci knowledge prerequisites.  Just bring a thoughtful mindset. This meetup is open to all on a first registration basis.


See you then...

Gary Deines

===============


PS:  As a preview see information at www.UMAKEU.com.  Or, if your first meeting, download the initial presentation slides (click here).  New presentation slides will be sent out a week in advance of this meeting.  Make sure you register at this site to get the slides (just become a group member).


PPS:  We are forming a lyceum for the intelligencia of the North Shore (Subject Matter Experts .. SMEs).  If you know someone who will contribute, please invite them.

results.description:
Saturday, April 2, 2015
12pm-1pm

BOSTON Surfing & SUP Surfing Chart Presentation on Surf Etiquette, Wave Selection and Ocean Safety
This is a brief chart presentation by me, Stacey Mac of <a>www.SUPSONAS.com,</a> in Boston. It will also be held at Boston Winery before the SUP SONAS Client Appreciation Wine Tasting & Pizza Party. It is for beginner surfers, stand up paddlesurfers or stand-up paddleboarders who are venturing out into the ocean. I am a stand up paddleboard and sup surf instructor and competitor in greater Boston, New England and Costa Rica and am based on the South Shore in Massachusetts. It will help you learn about how to pick and choose which waves are best, what types of waves there are, surf etiquette and how to behave in a line-up, how to safety maneuver your board so as not to hurt yourself, other surfers, other swimmers or your board, how to read online surf reports and more about ocean safety for surfing and stand up paddleboarding. It is a course great for anyone who will be venturing out into the waves on purpose or by accident :). I will also answer any other questions on board selection, how to get into the competitive circuit and what wetsuit to buy for the spring. Come mingle with other stand up paddleboarders and surfers. $5 to attend.


We will also have the following courses available at different times, so let me know if interested:

"Learn how to Stand Up Paddleboard. A Beginner, Indoor, On-land Lesson." ($10) "Learn how to SUP Surf. A Beginner, Indoor, On-land Lesson." ($10)

"Board Selection. A Presentation on the different paddleboards and why they range in price from $400 to $3000. ($10).

Directions:
Boston Winery located at:
26 Ericsson Street
Dorchester, MA

****If any Native is interested in organizing an event this year please come to Tony C's.

****If any Native has questions or ideas for the meetup please come to Tony C's.

 ****If any Native is interested in hosting an event for us then come to Tony C's and we will tell you how.

Jon and I have extremely busy and difficult schedules and would love to have some help with events.

The Red Sox Natives are 8 years old!

Eight years ago Natives Founder Jon Mason had a brilliant idea and formed this group. And here we are today approaching our 1700th Meetup!

Please join us at The New Tony C's Sports Bar at 1:00pm on Saturday, April 2 2016 to celebrate the Red Sox Natives story.

This is a members only event.

We will have a reserved table.

Stay for lunch, drinks, socializing...

Watch the Red Sox play their final 2016 Spring Training Game vs the Toronto Blue Jays from Montreal.  Game time is 1:05pm

All Red Sox Natives, Legacy Members, Organizers and Event Hosts are invited. Please RSVP to facilitate the Tony C's lunch table reservation. We will not be cross posting this event. Please wear your Red Sox apparel.

We will be taking predictions!

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. Tony C's staff may take credit cards and there will be no group bill if everyone communicates with their server in advance. Everyone is responsible for their own food and drinks.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill is a sports themed restaurant named to honor Red Sox legend and Massachusetts Native Tony Conigliaro. Tony C's has approximately 11000 square feet with a capacity of nearly 500 (including patio) and over 90 TV Screens including a Jumbotron.  It combines a fresh, house-made menu of American comfort food and the highest quality HD audiovisual system available. Classic and specialty cocktails, an extensive beer list and American wines are featured on the menu.

The Red Sox Natives have been organizing Sports viewing parties over the last several years with guests from several other invited groups attending. We have had a blast with up to 80 people attending at various locations in Boston, Somerville, Woburn and Wakefield. 

We hope to see you there!

Jon, Frank and The Red Sox Natives team

Postscript - We had a similar 5th Birthday Party Lunch 3 years ago and the Red Sox ended up winning the World Series, just saying and remembering!
results.name: Red Sox Natives 8 Year Birthday Lunch & Final Exibition Game vs Blue Jays

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 2, 1:30-4pm)

We'll talk about and practice pacing yourself. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

results.description:
Join us as we celebrate our Spring rebirth and meet at the India Pavilion restaurant in Central Square for a buffet lunch to celebrate the Equinox, on Saturday April 2 at 2 pm. A talk on the issues of "'spirituality' and naturalism" will follow. RSVP only if you plan to attend and purchase a meal at the restaurant as explained below.

Our guest speaker will be Tom Clark, founder of the Center for Naturalism and author of Encountering Naturalism: A Worldview and Its Uses. 

His title is "The Ordinary, and How to Get Out of It":

All sentient beings find themselves in what they can’t help but take as 'the ordinary': being alive with just this 'ordinary' set of characteristics and concerns. Worldview naturalism, based in a demanding commitment to empiricism, gives us an outside context that puts 'the ordinary' into a vaster perspective. How much is this extra-ordinary view like what others call 'Spirituality'? This empirically-based perspective can speak to our desires for truth, transcendence, and meaning. Thus we might live our everyday lives a bit more skillfully and compassionately-- and more attuned to the astonishing fact that we exist at all.

Tom Clark is also host of Naturalism.Org and a longtime associate of Greater Boston Humanists.

SIGN UPs: The Lunch Buffet at India Pavilion is $14 a person (includes tax and tip). To assure your place, please only say you will attend on MeetUp, here, if you are sure you are coming and will be paying for the buffet meal! Payment at the time of arrival will be accepted either as cash or as checks payable to Greater Boston Humanists.

PARKING is at meters along Green Street and in 2 lots off Green St. Parking should not be an issue at 2 PM. Please bring a lot of quarters although the parking lots should now have service boxes that accept credit cards. Of course, Central Square is easily accessible by Metro/T, and the restaurant is just a block from the Central Square station.
results.name: Spring Equinox Luncheon and Talk: "The Ordinary, and How to Get Out of It"
