results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
We are 1.2 million neighbors, friends, and community leaders who come together to create positive, lasting change in our communities and around the world.

My passion is to take our world class city of Cambridge, MA and make it the leader in community service.  And I need your help.  :)  We meet for lunch every Thursday in Harvard Square. 

Our differing occupations, cultures, and countries give us a unique perspective. Our shared passion for service helps us accomplish the remarkable.

WHAT MAKES US DIFFERENT?
Our distinct point of view and approach gives us unique advantages:

We see differently: Our multidisciplinary perspective helps us see challenges in unique ways.

We think differently: We apply leadership and expertise to social issues—and find unique solutions.

We act responsibly: Our passion and perseverance create lasting change.

We make a difference at home and around the world: Our members can be found in your community and across the globe.

HOW DO WE WORK?
Our impact starts with our members—people who work tirelessly with their clubs to solve some of our communities' toughest challenges. Their efforts are supported by Rotary International, our member association, and The Rotary Foundation, which turns generous donations into grants that fund the work of our members and partners around the world. Rotary is led by our members—responsible leaders who help to carry forward our organization's mission and values in their elected roles. I hope you join us and the world will live as one.  Please email me, [masked]  if you like what you here and want to become part of the solution.
results.name: Open enrollment in the largest community service club in the World

To Secure Your Spot for This Event, You Must Register Here

Attract, delight, and retain mobile users at scale 

How do you interact with every single user, on a personal basis, at a scale without going insane? How do you personalize your app experience and marketing messages to every user without hiring an army of marketers. Without customizing your messages to every single user, at every stage of the growth funnel, you'll never be able to scale, and your marketing will most likely fail and cause your startup to crash. In this webinar, you'll learn the most important 3 steps you need to nail to transform your business into a marketing machine that instantly turns every new users into long term happy users.

Why attend this webinar:

1. Learn the critical 3 steps of scaling your marketing for free, even if you have no marketing team

2. Discover the #1 reason why most app marketers fail at bringing back existing users and keep them happy (and what do instead).

3. Apply 1 simple hack to exponentially increase your retention rates

More information about the speaker:

Mobile Growth Academy - Nagi Salloum - Founder - Twitter @nagisalloum

Nagi has 12 years of marketing expertise and currently the founder of the Mobile Growth Academy, an online platform that offers mobile startups a step by step guide to help them market and grow their apps. Prior to that, Nagi was the head of global product marketing for Tango Messenger, a Silicon Valley company that raised over $350M and has 400M users worldwide. Nagi also served as the Chief Marketing Officer at N2V, a leading internet investment group, a regional marketing executive for Google, and as a regional brand manager for P&G . Nagi is also a board member, mentor and advisor to dozens of tech startups in Silicon Valley, Norway, Spain, Portugal, Mexico, UAE, UK, Germany, Egypt, Lebanon and many more.

With the forecast for a nice WARM DAY for Grilling, this is a FREE EVENT!  CALL 781-C-FRIARS for more information.


Thursday, April 7, 2016

Saint JOHN BAPTIST de la SALLE

  Please note: this is the first independent Meetup for the same day, see "Monastic Cooking Class: Seafood Pizza! Make, Cook & Eat/Evening Prayer for Grace" announcement for the second and next (and continual meeting or independent) Meetup gathering on April 7 at 7:00 PM.

From the blessings of a wealthy family, St. John Baptist de la Salle gave up fame & fortune to becme a priest and he took on the role  of a humble job as a teacher. He is the Patron Saint for teachers. 

We are in his honor cooking our own version of Monastic Seafood Pizza and to get an idea click on the link to see a different version of the recipe.

Please note: this is a second independent Meetup for the same day, see "Called to Communion" announcement for the previous and first (and continual meeting or independent) Meetup gathering on April 7 at 2:00 PM.

THE RADIO SHOW "CALLED TO COMMUNION"

We are inviting all our non-Catholic friends especially, along with our Catholic ones, as there will be an opportunity for interactive live radio correspondence on this Internationally broadcast show. Several telephones will be available to call and ask questions the Catholic Faith, particularly ones that non-Catholics may want clarified or even challenged. "What's preventing YOU from becoming a Catholic?" Perhaps something someone has told you, or maybe you just cannot figure out why the Church teaches something, or indeed if She even does! We are all called to Communion with Jesus Christ and the Holy Church that he founded. We already have at least a couple of our non-Catholic friends attending.

After the show we will pray from Psalms (Evening Prayer from the Divine Office), hold a brief Cooking Class and afterwards enjoy some food together.

The link for today's Prayer Daytime Prayer is at the following:

http://divineoffice.org/easter-w02-thu-dp2-current/?date=20160407 

Great radio talk-show with Dr. David Anders, a convert to the Catholic Faith. He shares his journey and enlightens us on Fullness of the Truth in the Catholic Church. We'll pray Evening Prayer after the show, maybe even call in during, and consider some local place for a bite to eat afterwards for anyone interested in continuing the day's discussions and friendship in Christ. Walk (just around the corner) to the Faneuil Street Entrance and Ring the Doorbell to Apartment #1. Call 781-C-FRIARS for more information. 

http://www.calledtocommunion.com/2010/09/called-to-communion-welcomes-david-anders/

This is a FREE EVENT! 

This is a FREE EVENT!  CALL 781-C-FRIARS for more information.

We will also plan upcoming meetups with Liturgical Hours, the Monastic Cooking Club, etc., including a "Live the Fast" day with reference to http://www.livethefast.org and formation of "Civic Friars" in conjunction with the Civic Friary® and the new School of Monastic Cooking. Call 781-C-FRIARS for more information. 

Additional Information for hearing the show:

via computer: http://tunein.com/radio/WQOM-1060-s27480/

via Radio Dial: 1060AM

via Network (Station of the Cross):http://www.thestationofthecross.com 

via Website:http://www.thestationofthecross.com/stations/boston/

via Radio Station website: http://www.1060catholic.org/

It is hoped you can attend, but there is great opportunity via the above options through computer, podcasts, etc. to hear the show. Please give us feedback on your experience! Call 781-C-FRIARS

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
What is a “learning space”? Who belongs in “learning spaces”? The definition might once have been clear, but the impact of emerging technologies and global communications has created instant access to resources and vast domains of knowledge, blurring clearly defined boundaries and extending the learning experience beyond traditional classroom settings. This creates a rich, fertile, and open field for innovations in learning.

THE MEME invites you to an evening of conversation with experienced leaders as we explore fundamental questions about the future of where we learn and how we learn. We will explore the design of learning spaces, the activities that take place within them, and the role of technology. 

Of interest to the community of educators, administrators, journalists, technology researchers, entrepreneurs, designers, buyers and builders of education technology.

We have three speakers confirmed for the panel: Saeed Arida (NuVu), Nina Huntemann (edX), and Daniel Wilson (Project Zero).

EVENT DETAILS:
6PM Doors Open
7-8:30PM Panel Discussion
8:30-9PM Wrap up Networking

results.name: Reimagining the Learning Environment

In addition to networking with the women and men shaping the cannabis industry in Massachusetts, our April 7 event will comprise a panel discussion and Q&A with Regina Hufnagel and Will Luzier on the state of cannabis in Massachusetts, as well as an interactive personal pitch development workshop featuring Donna Rheaume.


EVENT AGENDA


6 to 6:30 p.m.: Registration, networking, and updates
6:30 to 7:15: Panel discussion on the state of legal cannabis in Mass. followed by Q&A
7:15 to 8:00: Presentation and live workshop on lobbying, personally and professionally, for access to cannabis in Mass.
8:00 to 9:00: Open networking

Click here to register.

SPEAKERS

Regina Hufnagel is a former federal corrections officer who now sits on the speaker's bureau of Law Enforcement Against Prohibition (LEAP). After a stint in Bosnia in support of Operation Joint Forge, Regina began employment with the Federal Bureau of Prisons as a Correctional Officer, where she witnessed first-hand how the drug war affected people who committed “crimes without victims.”

www.leap.cc

Will Luzier, a former assistant attorney general and executive director of the Massachusetts Interagency Council on Substance Abuse and Prevention, is campaign manager of the Campaign to Regulate Marijuana Like Alcohol in Massachusetts.

www.regulatemassachusetts.org

Veteran communications and public affairs professional Donna Rheaume is the founder of MMPR, a PR firm that serves registered marijuana dispensaries (RMDs) in Massachusetts. Donna has a background in public health and over 20 years of experience in journalism, public relations and government relations.

www.vgrlawfirm.com/medical-marijuana-public-relations/

results.description:
Join us for a fun, stimulating evening of group critique and discussion. 

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers. 

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion. Please note: In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, in winter, spring, summer, and fall.

results.description:
You keep hearing about the R programming language and no wonder. R is the premier and most widely used Analytics language. Azure Machine Learning Studio is built on it and Microsoft recently acquired the R platform vendor, Revolution Analytics, to integrate R into SQL Server 2016. The need to learn R is clear. This presentation will give you the basics about R programming. We will start with a background on what R is and where it came from. Then you will learn how to install the language shell and R Studio, the development environment. You’ll learn about the unique vector based architecture of R which makes it such a powerful analysis tool. Through examination of examples you will learn the about the language. We'll also see some examples of R's powerful visualization features. The goal of this session is to demystify R and give you a basic understanding of R programming. You will leave feeling that R is fun! The focus is on the programming language so only a minimal understanding of statistics is needed.


Pizza is going to be served at 6:30 courtesy of Foliage

About Bryan Cafferky...

Bryan Cafferky, of BPC Global Solutions LLC, is an independent Business Intelligence consultant with decades of experience in information technology focused on the Microsoft stack. Bryan is the author of Pro PowerShell for Database Developers published by Apress and available on Amazon. He is the founder and leader of the SQL PASS chapter, The Rhode Island Microsoft Business Intelligence User Group. Bryan has spoken on a number of subjects at various PASS chapters, Code Camps, and SQL Saturdays. He has worked in banking, insurance, Internet/Ecommerce, utilities, and health care. Bryan holds an undergraduate degree in Computer Information Systems from Bryant University and a Masters in Business Administration from Bentley University. Nothing makes Bryan happier than to learn and pass the knowledge on to others. You can contact Bryan at [masked] and on LinkedIn at https://www.linkedin.com/in/bryancafferky. You can join his PASS Chapter at: http://www.meetup.com/The-RI-Microsoft-BIUG/. See his blog at <a>www.sql-fy.com.</a>
results.name: Introducing the R Programming Language

results.description:
Welcome,

Thank you all for signing up for the Meetup.  As I said, this is a bit of an experiment, so I don't have a full-fledged plan for what it will entail.  I decided it would be best to set a date, time, and location, for the initial meeting and work from there.  

Thus, if you're interested in attending, please RVSP for the initial meetup.  I set it up for a few weeks from now to give some time to create a more focused theme for the meeting As the date approaches, I'll probably develop a more specific topic of discussion.  

Edit:  I've picked the topic of "Increasing the minimum wage" for the first topic.  I'll be posting or sending out some articles on the subject beforehand so that people can have a baseline for discussion.  

Edit 2: I put together an overview of articles on the subject.  Obviously, discussion won't be limited to these, but I figured it would give people a base understanding of the issue.  If you have any others you would like to suggest, let me know. 

And, don't worry, they're pretty short (1-2 pages).  There's one long-form article, and one book suggestion if people are interested in reading further. There are also two activist groups if people are interested in getting involved.   

Last edit (hopefully):  I decided to cap the meetup at 10, otherwise it could get overwhelming.  If you change your mind about coming, please change your RSVP to no so that someone from the waitlist can join. 

Best,

Kevin

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Thurs April 7, 6:30-9pm)

results.description:
Come join us for a lively book discussion - The Boys in the Boat: Nine Americans and Their Epic Quest for Gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics by Daniel James Brown.

The #1 New York Times–bestselling story about American Olympic triumph in Nazi Germany. It is the kind of nonfiction book that reads like a novel.

Out of the depths of the Depression comes an irresistible story about beating the odds and finding hope in the most desperate of times—the improbable, intimate account of how nine working-class boys from the American West showed the world at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin what true grit really meant.

It was an unlikely quest from the start. With a team composed of the sons of loggers, shipyard workers, and farmers, the University of Washington’s eight-oar crew team was never expected to defeat the elite teams of the East Coast and Great Britain, yet they did, going on to shock the world by defeating the German team rowing for Adolf Hitler. The emotional heart of the tale lies with Joe Rantz, a teenager without family or prospects, who rows not only to regain his shattered self-regard but also to find a real place for himself in the world. Drawing on the boys’ own journals and vivid memories of a once-in-a-lifetime shared dream, Brown has created an unforgettable portrait of an era, a celebration of a remarkable achievement, and a chronicle of one extraordinary young man’s personal quest. 


This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink, snack or lite bite. Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Coffee Loft.

Please be considerate and change your RSVP if you cannot attend!!

results.description:
The Magical Landscapes of North West Argentina and the Art of the Modern Print with Lauren Hefferon and Eric Luden

An evening of learning, beautiful images and abundant Argentinian white wine and empanadas with fellow photographer friends.

FREE event Hosted by Digital Silver Imaging & Travel Vision Journeys

Northwest Argentina is an enormously photogenic and pristine region consisting of the provinces of Catamarca, Jujuy, Salta, Santiago del Estero and Tucumán. In her lively and informative presentation, Lauren Hefferon, world traveler and photographer and founder and director of Travel Vision Journeys, will share the images of renown photographer Ossian Lindholm and take you on a photographic tour of Northwest Argentina and its incredible landscape diversity consisting of five distinct biomes: the sub-Andean humid sierras of the east, fertile valleys, and the canyons, the high mountains of the Andes and the Altiplano or Puna.

Lauren will share her view of the role of photography in conservation and how photographers of all abilities and interests can make the world a better place with the click of a shutter or the tap of an IPHONE. You will walk away with a special understanding and appreciation of this unique and little known part of the world and be inspired by Lauren’s passion for photography and creating endearing images that poignantly communicate our special and symbiotic relationship to Mother Earth.

Following Lauren’s presentation, Eric Luden co-owner of Digital Silver Imaging will talk about how you can take your precious images and turn them into prints. His discussion would include a brief summary of what has changed with digital printing from the old film days to digitac. Eric will explain their unique B&W process - 1 of 10 labs in the world capable of this unique print process, and we have trademarked ours as DSI Digital Silver Prints®. We are also a Hahnemühle paper Certified Digital Studio. Eric will explain the various paper choices and benefits. This seminar is sponsored by Digital Silver Imaging, and Travel Vision Journeys. The mission of Travel Vision Journeys is to use the camera literally as a lens of learning and discovery. TravelVision Journeys are active photo vacations that invigorate and immerse guests into the nature, culture and landscape of the most stunning places in the world.

After our minds are full with new ideas, it will be time for a taste of Argentinian wine and empanadas. Join us!
results.name: FREE!Enjoy gorgeous photos of Argentina, learn about the Art of the Modern Print

results.description:
Location Details: 

100 Holton is a big building, and #3 is located in the alley around the back side of the building. When you pull up to 100 Holton, you will need to drive down the alley to the right of the building and then down back behind the building and there you will find #3. You will see a big arrow that is pointing to the door that is made up of Christmas Lights!

There is plenty of parking right outside the entrance. (If there are any issues you can contact host Owen Mack at (617)-823-9286.

About:

Do you ever find your self on a website, and your computer dies so you have no choice but to pick up where you left off but on your mobile device? Are you ever shopping last minute, searching for a product to buy online and pick up in store - with no luck? We are here to introduce you to a concept that helps make this experiences such as this as easy as possible, and thats omnichannel commerce.

Omnichannel commerce needs to be able to perfect one thing, and that is brand continuity and seamless purchasing and fulfillment across all channels. We want to invite you to learn more about what it means to be an omnichannel merchant, how omnichannel effects eCommerce, and an update on how Magento provides omnichannel solutions to merchants everyday. We will be hearing from Ashley Molloy from Magento, who has extensive expertise in omnichannel eCommerce.

Agenda:

6:30-7:00: Food, Drinks, and Networking

7:00-7:20: Presentation

7:20-7:45: Questions, Final Networking, and Closing Remarks
results.name: Omnichannel eCommerce

results.description:
Accompany us as an amazing array of advocates advise and astound about application accoutrement at our April assembly! As always, your attendance is appreciated amongst an audience of all attributes!

In typical BostonJS fashion, we're taking things a bit too literally and brought you the best A's we can think of, including "A" quality work and Alliteration for our attendees!

We're also quite eager, you know, to share an amazing April sponsor: Eager.io!

Topics & Speakers: 

Redux with Riz w/ Ari Rizzitano
Why Internationalization is Accessibility w/ Aria Stewart
My Favorite JavaScript Quotes w/ Aaron Sikes

---

Redux with Riz w/ Ari Rizzitano
twitter: https://twitter.com/arizzitano
github: https://github.com/arizzitano
website: http://www.arizzitano.com/

Redux is a lightweight, functional JS state manager. It has the one-way data flow and React-readiness of Flux, with a dash of functional funk inspired by Elm. While it's mainly used with React, it is framework-agnostic and works with any view library. Its global store and one-way write logic makes for lucid code and quick debugging.  My talk will cover Redux's internals and API, its read/write patterns, how to integrate it with a React project, and how to unit test Redux code effectively.

---
Why Internationalization is Accessibility w/ Aria Stewart
twitter: https://twitter.com/aredridel
github: https://github.com/aredridel
website: http://aredridel.dinhe.net/

We work hard to make sure that people can interact with the software we make, but all too often we forget that words on the page are what really matter. If they can't be understood or make poor impressions, our work is for nothing.

---
My Favorite JavaScript Quotes w/ Aaron Sikes
twitter: https://twitter.com/courajs
github: https://github.com/courajs
website: http://aaron.sikes.io/

JavaScript is a very expressive language. See how it can express the whole range of human emotion - from exasperation and despair, to altruism and joy. Hear about success and failure from the greats. Feel free to pin any of these to your mirror :)

#FollowYourBliss #BeYourBestSelf #breathe #quotestagram #js

Tonight, as a group, you will get to experience the timeline both out of and in hypnosis.  I will be delivering a technique that I have created using imagery, light, and the past and future timelines.

In Lexington we typically have subjects focused mainly on hypnosis.


Come and Have Fun.

Kevin Martin, CHT

results.description:
Crossroads Irish Pub (Boston,  Beacon St and Mass Ave intersection) 7 pm to 10 pm

Due to requests and great turnout, Japanese Evening Table is going back to Crossroads! Grab a few drinks and some delicious cheap bar food. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking in the area is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. Also, watch out for those hidden street cleaning signs! If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway to Hynes or bus #1 to stop between Beacon and Marlborough.

Ordering at Crossroads: 

1) Order all your drinks and food at the bar. 

2) Start a tab (付け) or pay as you go. Don't forget to tip. 

See you there!


~Lindsay

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.

We will be addressing all these common questions, and many more, during our evening TLC Parent Workshop on Toilet Training. At The Loved Child, we realize parents can feel overwhelmed by the well-meaning but often contradictory advice from friends & family and the numerous on-line resources and books. results.description:
What if experiencing good luck 
                     is not simply having good luck?

• What if there was actually a science to creating good luck?

• What are the qualities, beliefs and actions that people who consistently experience good luck all demonstrate?

• What are you doing consciously and unconsciously when you are "in the zone" and life is easy and "good luck" is present?


Peter Felsmann offers an opportunity for each of us to become more aware of how we each can have and create more "good luck" in our lives.

Join us for a webinar with Peter Felsmann, based in Mexico City, Peter is a Productivity Guru and founder of Perform Productivity Solutions for Spanish, Portuguese, and Italian speaking countries. He has over 25 years of experience facilitating personal and professional seminars; Culture Change, productivity, team-building, communication, teamwork, and leadership training; and peer mentoring sessions.

Peter will also be flying to Boston to facilitate the Insight I "Awakening Heart Seminar" April 29th - May 1st.

You can also join us April 14th with Insight Facilitator Janet Parker who will be leading an evening workshop titled Relationships: Seeing Through the Eyes of the Heart.
results.name: Insight: The Secret of having Good Luck

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

Note:  Pose will be the same as the Saturday 3-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $90, non-members for $110.    Four hours each Friday morning, 10:00- 2:00pm. You can come individual days by paying $20 (members) or $30 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $90 or $110 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. We'll wait about 15 minutes before starting the walk.  Running really late? You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk.  

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the group with the strollers hanging out in front of the visitor center.

 SPC members have long expressed an interest in an additional channel for unstructured networking and just plain schmoozing about their business triumphs and trials.
Here's how it works: You just show up! No need to pay a fee.
Rick Pollack of Presentation Medic, a member of the SPC Board, has volunteered to anchor this gathering. This meeting is a bring your own agenda, or just enjoy lunch with other consultants.
Find yourself something appealing to nosh on, settle at the cash register, and join the group. We've picked 1 p.m. on a Friday as our start time to avoid the crush and let people take as much time as they feel they can afford...and maybe start a new conversation they can pick up later!
Mark your calendar now ... you don't even have to sign up on our website!

• Founded in 1998, Harvard China Forum is the leading student organized China conference in the world. For nineteen years, the Forum has provided an unrivaled platform for world leaders to debate and address issues that will impact the future of China. 

The 19th Harvard China Forum will be held on April 8th-10th, 2016 (Friday evening through Sundayafternoon) at Hynes Convention Center, Boston. With over 100 speakers and 1,200 attendees, the conference will help you to not just enhance your understanding of China, but also forge valuable connections and access life-changing opportunities.

This year's Harvard China Forum will feature over 100 speakers from industries including business, art, manufacturing, music, hospitality, healthcare, among others.

Confirmed speakers include (partial list, in alphabetical order):

And many more!

Speakers featured in each panel will be released periodically through our Wechat account. Please scan the QR code in the event cover photo to follow our Wechat account in order to receive the latest updates.

This year's HCF will also feature a Pitch Competition, a platform for entrepreneurs to present their China-related startup ideas. Participants will receive feedback from seasoned judges, who may choose to directly invest in those startups. 

For additional information and tickets please visit www.harvardchina.org/register.

results.description:
Swanky Beacon Hill has a seedy history! Watch this one minute youtube video,

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TqixK5V7BTc 

Carrie Nation is  somewhat pricey but a great atmosphere, huge, capacity 360, intended to be a re-creation of the pubs before prohibition. Manager Frank is the nicest guy, he is pretty intimidating in size, yet has the heart of a teddy bear.
http://www.carrienationcocktailclub.com/about-us-2/

It's named after Carrie Nation, the symbolic initiator of  Prohibition. She and her gang used to go around smashing the windows of pubs with a hatchet. Their motto was, " he whose lips touch wine shall not touch mine".

https://encrypted-tbn3.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSKCuWtVy4EzaOpcVP4ICMp9crV3TNH5v-aUrG0dpHCfgiQ5jipFA

This is a rolling come and go as you can event. Some folks come just for a drink, others hang out and chat for a few hours. There's good food here too but there is no pressure to order anything.

Please pay as you go! MBTA to Park St. (green/ Red line), then a pretty short walk up the hill.

Look forward to seeing you again!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the  "speakeasy" room up the stairs in the back by the 2nd bar there.
results.name: Meetup for Ages 40 Plus @ the Carrie Nation, Boston

ONE Cantonese Event each Friday evening - with SEVERAL ACCOMPLISHED Cantonese speakers/teachers/guides - at the Huntington Avenue YMCA/Hastings Hall - Room # 101

The ONLY entrance is at 320 Huntington Avenue.

The weekly Cantonese-English chat begins with a one-hour level 1 Cantonese language class followed by a free chat. 

<a href="https://www.google.com/maps/dir/">https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until mid-April, Dandan's YMCA-based Cantonese-English class and chat will be in in Boston YMCA 101.

Dandan 'Danni' Mai and Xiao 'Cecelia' Xiu, from the PRC (and NEU), host these friendly meetups (in Boston YMCA 101), and Frankie Presta may also instruct.

* Cantonese speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?  
* English speakers want to learn Cantonese?  
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Cantonese?

Schedule: 
6:00 - 7:00PM - Cantonese class 
7:00 - 9:00PM - Bilingual free chat.

6:00 - 7:00 - 廣東話班
7:00 - 9:00 - 雙語談話

* Green Line E-Line comes above ground to Northeastern, and the YMCA is around the corner.
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, walking through Northeastern University.
* Walking from Brookline is about 15 minutes.
* MFA, Wentworth, College, and Harvard's LMA are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue. 
* Route 9 comes near the area, via Brookline.
* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find).

New England Conservatory (NEU) is on the corner, followed by The Huntington Avenue YMCA, and then the entrance to Hasting fall is at the end of that block at 320 Huntington Avenue.  This building is OWNED BY NEU.

By MBTA, get off at 

• Northeastern University stop on Huntington Avenue E-Line (MBTA Green E) 
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on the Orange Line (then walk around NEC to YMCA).
• New England Conservatory stop on #39 bus
• Massachusetts Avenue stop on #1 bus from Harvard Square (then walk around NEC to YMCA).

results.description:
An evening dedicated to Queer Women of Color in film. 

The LOCS Collective, in partnership with the 32nd Annual Wicked Queer Boston's LGBT Film Festival & Queer Women of Color Media Arts Project (QWOCMAP) , presents a screening of various short films followed by a soiree at Tiger Mama. 

About the QWOC Films:

Singer, choir director and musician, Melanie DeMore, shows children and adults how to be Free In Song as she sows the seeds of cultural activism and history. The passion between two queer Black women ripples across the vastness of decades in Your Kiss. What could Possibly be the connection between wooded trails, sunny BART stops and floral sheets? A journey through queer and cultural identity creates the broth that flavors Life Y Pozole. From the roots of struggle, My Beautiful Resistance grows vibrantly for an undocumented, queer, person of color. The support of Girls You Know inspires a young girl to mold her environment. Judgement within queer identity leads to The Un/Belonging. With her alluring Heft, a queer Black woman in the East Bay draws a bevy of suitors and scoundrels.

~Free community event ~ Appetizers 

Reserve your seat (s) !

Sponsored by Fenway Women's Health , QWOCMAP, Edge Media Network , and Wicked Queer
results.name: Beautiful Possibilities - Queer Women of Color Cinema Pt. 1 & Soiree

results.description:
And so, the quest for Finding Pedro continues - this time by fighting against cancer at Relay for Life! I'm proud to say that this will be my third year leading a team, and it would be an honor to attend this event with all of you =)

WHAT IS RELAY FOR LIFE?
For those of you unfamiliar with Relay, it is a community event where teams who have been raising money for the American Cancer Society come together for a night of honoring those who are suffering from or who have lost their lives to cancer. Of course, this night is filled with plenty of fun activities, and is an exciting, meaningful event ideal for bringing a community together!

HOW DO I JOIN PEDRO'S TEAM?
1) Click this link: http://main.acsevents.org/site/TR/?team_id=1992831&pg=team&fr_id=73142
2) Didn't work? Go to relayforlife.org, then click 'Find an Event.' Find the event that matches the date and address listed here. Then, find Pedro's Friends under the team names.
3) Register, and you're ready to go! I'll send you a message once I get confirmation you've joined.

OTHER INFO
1) Commitment: Yes, this IS a 12 hour event. No, you don't have to stay for the entire time. EVENT GOAL: Since cancer never sleeps, the idea is that at least one team member will be walking around the track at all times. Want to walk early, then go party hard? Great. More of a night owl, and want to keep the fun times rolling at 3am? That works, too!
2) If you can't commit: Then donate, and support your friends in a worthy cause! Cancer has touched the lives of countless loved ones around us, so please click the 'Donate to this Team' button, or dedicate a Luminara to honor a loved one! It feels good =)
3) Spreading the Word! I highly encourage you to share your personal page on Facebook, through email, and certainly through word of mouth! My team fundraised nearly $5500 last year, and I'd love for FP to break that record! Let's join together to raise money in hopes of find a cure at last!

NEED THE TEAM LINK AGAIN?
http://main.acsevents.org/site/TR/?team_id=1992831&pg=team&fr_id=73142

MORE QUESTIONS?
Facebook me, or email me at: [masked]

I hope you join!
results.name: Pedro's Friends Fight Cancer: Relay For Life (Important Info. in Description)

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

7:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

7:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

7:20 - Play!!!!!!

9:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: The field is right next to Alewife station on the Red Line. There is also plenty of parking provided no one else is using the field. (Not an issue in the winter.)
results.name: Friday Night Time Ultimate @ Russell Field

results.description:
Meetup at MetroRock Gym in Everett, offering both toprope and lead


Meet at the left-side hexagonal picnic table next to the bench and cubbies.

I (Jens) will go up to the picnic table area from 7 - 7:15 PM to meet people who prefer to show up at the regular MeetUp time. Please check  the whiteboard near the bathrooms for a description of what I'm wearing. If anyone else arrives early, please write "MEETUP" and your name & what you are wearing on the Whiteboard.

If you have not already done so, please post a clear face picture of yourself on your profile so that I and other members can recognize you.

If arriving later, just come find us on the walls. Hopefully you can recognize me (see "Event Host" right) from my picture.

If you've never climbed here before, you'll need to take & pass a belay test for rope climbing. Call the gym or see the website below for more info. Full-access Day Pass $22. Bouldering-Only Pass $18. Free pizza for students.

More info and directions: http://www.metrorock.com/
results.how_to_find_us: At the picknic table next to the cubbies

results.description:
DELICIOUS DINNER

(and Take-Out)

Prepared by

DAVID SNIECKUS

- MACROBIOTIC CHEF AND COUNSELOR - At 7 p.m.

at David’s, Margaret’s and Abigail's home in Newton, MA

April 8, 2016 Menu

Carrot Soup

Udon Noodles

Tofu with Onions

Broccoli, Kale, and Carrots

Mashed Winter Squash

Green Salad

Red Radish Pickles and Napa Chocolate Pudding with Raspberries

Kukicha Tea

(See detailed logistics below.)

**************************

Followed by a presentation on

The Discovery of the Brain's Neuroplasticity as an Explanation for many Miracles of Physical Healing

with Barry Harris

Barry will introduce us to the primary evidence that as quantum physics explains, consciousness creates the brain, and the brain does not create consciousness as previously believed. The presentation will be more "good news" that we have been "Beggars At God's Banquet," unaware we are creators, and thus unaware of our incredible powers.

Suggested Donation: $10

About Barry:

Barry Harris majored in quantum physics in college, attended a “New Universe” workshop taught by David Bohm (one of the most significant theoretical physicists of the 20th century), and Karl Pribram (who showed the brain as the decoder of holograms), and took a weeklong course with Karl Pribram’s graduate student assistant.

Barry also worked at the Hippocrates Institute in Boston, writing health booklets for Dr. Ann Wigmore, discoverer of wheatgrass and founder of the live food movement. Hippocrates Institute is a unique healing center with a powerful spiritual focus, and an extreme dietary regime which often attracted clients who Western medicine had labeled terminally ill. While there Barry witnessed many miraculous recoveries.

Later Barry witnessed more miracles while working for four years in various centers around the U.S. founded by Viktoras Kulvinskas, Dr. Wigmore's Director. Obsessed with the secret to miracles, Barry did 20 years of independent research connecting quantum physics to Energy Medicine, cellular biology, neurophysiology, mind/body medicine, effect of emotions on health, etc.

Barry's research has been the source for the course "Beggars At God's Banquet: Miracles Are Our Birthright" which he has been presenting for the past nine years. Barry's book "Beggars At God's Banquet" based on the contents of the course will be published by X-Libris Publishing in the spring.

Barry is also a singer/voice teacher who teaches "Voice as a Path of Spiritual and Emotional Healing". His voice students learn the relationship of ego to breath patterns, and how to surrender control to a higher power. Barry is qualified to teach about miracles, because he had his own miracle. He restored his singing voice by recognizing the need for spiritual grace and surrender of control to a higher power, after Western doctors said he had damaged his voice beyond repair.

Barry can be reached at [masked].

**************************

Most ingredients are organic and of the highest standards.

Come be in community and enjoy a healthy meal!

Call (617)[masked] or e-mail [masked]
for reservations and directions.

results.description:
From the dawn of the digital age we have been experimenting with the capabilities of software in the music production industry, especially in the realm of synthesis and sound.

https://youtu.be/Ig6vIRmfoNI

Inspired by the form and function of hardware synthesizers, software synthesizers open up a whole new area of sonic capability. In this workshop we will discuss the pro's and con's of software synthesis vs. hardware synthesis and where the two intersect. We will also take a look at some software synthesizers that are "must-haves" in any producers studio and use them to make some sounds from scratch.

Please make sure to RSVP & Reserve your tickets:

https://www.facebook.com/events/462431363951728/ 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/software-synthesis-48-free-tickets-24016432797
results.name: Software Synthesis [4/8] #FREE

results.description:
Hello BSAP Sisters!


You are invited to our monthly Bible Study, Food, and Fellowship!


This group is a great place to get to know other women in the Boston area by studying the Word of God, encouraging one another in our work/scholarship, and building a social network in an informal environment.  We discuss a variety of topics that are relevant to our growth as individuals and communities.  Feel free to invite other sisters, and bring a small dish or a snack to share with the group (I will provide beverages, as well as cups/plates/utensils). 

Buses close to my home: 87, 77, 79, 350 (Red Line access), and 80 (Green Line access).  Check https://www.google.com/maps for exact directions.  Free street parking also available.

If you cannot make this event and have already said you're attending, please be sure to update your RSVP status.  Thank you!

Blessings, 

Khalilah

BSAP Ministry Team

results.description:
A Free Public Talk

Stan Grof, M.D., Ph.D. is a world-renowned psychiatrist researching the healing potential of non-ordinary states of consciousness. An early pioneer in lsd psychotherapy and consciousness studies, and a founding member of the Transpersonal School of psychology, his groundbreaking theories have influenced the integration of western psychology with science and spirituality through his brilliant mapping of the transpersonal dimension. During this free public talk we will discuss Stan's life and career, including his influence on the field of psychology and other areas of contemporary society.

“Consciousness does not just passively reflect the objective material world; it plays an active role in creating reality itself.”
— Stanislav Grof, from The Holotropic Mind

Following the talk there will be opportunities for further discussions and the presenters will be on hand to answer questions.


This event precedes a day-long Holotropic Breathwork event. While registration for the workshop is not required for attendance of this free talk, it is highly recommended that anyone thinking of attending the workshop also attend this talk.

Refreshments will be served.
results.name: Healing Our Deepest Wounds: The Life & Work of Stanislav Grof MD PhD

results.description:
Join us for an evening of fun and connection as we play 3 communication games where we get the opportunity to say the truth and be real with each other (no touching and no one takes off any clothes). It's a great start to your evening! 

Imagine meeting new people in an environment where everyone feels comfortable to be themselves. It’s a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation—a place where everyone gets to say the truth. Through other people putting quality attention on you, and asking you questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening—really listening—to your responses, you have the opportunity to examine yourself. It’s a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good, which allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

You can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you. You don't have to do anything you don't want to, or answer any questions you don't want to answer. The games are designed to create the sensations in your body that you might have during Orgasmic Meditation* without having to actually do the practice—just through talking. What comes up might surprise you.

Even in a room full of strangers, it's amazing how connected we can end up feeling when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston. 

*At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation, which class or private training you can take with our masterful teachers and coaches, and what we have to offer so you can have more connection, authenticity, and play in your life!

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time—we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square or Alewife station.

Nicole Daedone (founder of Orgasmic Meditation) on the science of OM:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qg59pToG-Bk&feature=youtu.be
results.name: TurnON Boston

9:30-Midnight DJ’d Dance

8:00 - 9:15pm Critical Mass Drummers

Jimi and Morwen Two Feathers, Rodger Osgood, Jim Salem,
Jeff Lowe, and Joel Gendler wIth other friends.

"We are drummers that love to play and interact with dancers"

9:15-Midnight: DJ Favorites compiled by Rose

—Come dance to your favorite Dance Friday songs to launch the weekend.

Dance with us from 8:00 pm - midnight at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

Each spring the Movement Collective, through Dance Friday, hosts a full weekend of Dance Events and classes for Dance New England (DNE).

In 2016 the DNE Weekend will be held April 8th, 9th and 10th. To register online click here.

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.


Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join us for a night of west coast swing. We offer a beginner ("Level 1", meant for those with little/no experience), intermediate ("Level 2", meant for those who have mastered the Left Side Pass, Right Side Pass, and Sugar Push), and advanced ("Level 3", meant for those who have mastered whips, tucks, and fundamental techniques) classs from 8:30-9:30pm. If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-12pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, country and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Second-Friday-of-the-Month West Coast Swing Classes & Social Dance!

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet 15 minutes before the scheduled time and to the right of the line in front of the Astronomy building on the roof of the Museum of Science to be with the group. The Meetup group will wait for 10 minutes and then get in line.
results.name: Astronomy After Hours - Museum of Science

results.description:
Audien has released many singles and remixes for electronic record labels including Enhanced, Perceptive, Armada, Black Hole, and Nervous. His tracks have appeared on Corsten's Countdown, Tiësto's Club Life, Above & Beyond's Trance Around The World, and Armin van Buuren's A State of Trance compilations. In 2012, Audien began to include elements of progressive house into his music with the release of "These Are The Days". Audien's August 2012 release, "Eventide," is noted for being played by Above & Beyond during their DJ set at the 2012 Electric Daisy Festival in Las Vegas. Audien's track "Sup" was featured by Dutch icon Hardwell on episode 87 of Hardwell on Air.  In 2013, Above & Beyond premiered Audien's track, "Wayfarer" as the first song ever played on Above & Beyond Group Therapy. 


SOUNDCLOUD | FACEBOOK | TWITTER | INSTAGRAM

Price: $25, Pay in Advance or more at the door.

results.description:
Since 1972, SpeakOUT has brought committed and enthusiastic LGBTQIA folks together in empowering trainings to share our personal stories and learn how to engage with a variety of audiences. SpeakOUT's mission is to create a world free of homo-bi-trans-phobia and other forms of prejudice by telling the truths of our lives. We speak from our hearts. We speak from our own experiences. We speak to dispel stereotypes. And we speak to let other members of the LGBTQ community know they are not alone. We invite you to join us for our 2016 Spring Speaker Training.

We'll gather for a full day of learning the skills that will prepare you to go out to schools, colleges, businesses, and religious organizations and tell your own story in an effective and personal way. Novice and veteran speakers alike will learn and practice valuable skills like setting the right tone, overcoming fear, handling difficult questions, and crafting your personal story. 


• Breakfast, lunch, drinks and snacks will be supplied. 


• Cost: $75, $35 for seniors/students.


• Inquire about group rates and sliding scale.


• Pre-registration required.  (RSVP'ing here is not enough.)

For full registration details or to register, visit bit.ly/1MO0Zhh. Also feel free to email [masked] or call[masked]-9390.

results.description:
Join us for our weekly weekend run! We'll be meeting in Back Bay and logging some miles around Boston. All paces and runner levels are welcome!

During the winter months, we'll be meeting at the Boston Marathon RunBase on Boylston street for our Saturday runs. They have lockers and showers available for your use though you'll need to provide your own lock if you plan to use a locker.

Please post your desired pace and distance when you RSVP.

For this weekend’s run we have three route options. All three start out by taking Gloucester to Comm Ave and then heading west. For the 5.5 mile route runners will take a left on Harvard St and head south to Beacon St, then heading back to RunBase. For the 8 mile route, runners will continue on Comm Ave until its intersection with Chestnut Hill Ave, just before the reservoir. At that point runners will take a left on Chestnut Hill Ave and then another left onto Beacon St to head back to RunBase. For the 12 Mile route, runners will cross Chestnut Hill Ave and take a left onto Chestnut Hill Driveway just past the reservoir. Runners will take the Driveway to Beacon St and take a right to continue heading west. Runners will take a right on Hobart Rd shortly after the BC campus, heading north to join the marathon course on Comm Ave. 5.5 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6837482


8 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6837484


12 Mile Route: http://www.gmap-pedometer.com/?r=6837484

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)
results.how_to_find_us: The WORD is out, n' spreading!

results.description:
Most experts recommend RAW capture to obtain the highest quality results. This session will explore the reasons behind this recommendation by looking at what RAW files actually contain and the advantages they provide over JPEG files. It will also include a discussion of the digital implementation of ISO, its relationship to noise, and how to minimize noise at capture time. We will then move on to a detailed look at how your camera's histograms and highlight alerts are generated and how to use them to properly assess your RAW exposures. A conceptual understanding of this underlying digital technology will enable you to make better and more informed choices in the field to obtain maximum image quality.

The day will conclude with an overview and introduction to the post-processing tools and workflow needed to handle RAW files.

The presentation will start with basic concepts and build on them in a step by step manner to provide an in-depth treatment of these key aspects of digital imaging technology.  This approach which will make the session useful for both beginners and for more experienced photographers who do not yet feel they are in complete command in the digital world.  There will also be plenty of time for questions to better insure that everyone derives the maximum benefit from the class.

The class will start at 9 AM and we will break at Noon for lunch on your own (with plenty of choices within a 5-10 minute drive).  We will reconvene at 1:30 PM and the day will conclude at 4:30 PM.

Attendance will be limited to the first 20 people to sign up.

The $10 fee will go toward the room rental cost.
results.name: A Behind The Scenes Look At RAW files, ISO, Noise & Histograms

results.description:
We'll hike an a 8-9 mile loop encompassing sections of the Coffehouse Loop and Midstate Trail northward to the trailhead on Route 16 and return to  Wallum Lake via the Schmidt Trail. This trek will be on footpaths and unpaved roads and will cross the Southern New England Trunkline trail (an old railroad grade) jeep roads, and old Southwest Main Street.

Douglas State Forest consists of 5,525-acres located  bordering both Rhode Island and Connecticut.  The forest features a nearly unbroken forest canopy and rare Atlantic white cedar swamp, which has been  designated as a Massachusetts Wildland.. Although the terrain is fairly level it is so strewn with rocks, boulders and bedrock exposures that it's easy to see why early settlers passed this place by, leaving the area almost as uninhabited today as it was back then. The AMC MassachusettsTrail Guide states that this section of the Midstate Trail is "in many respects the most remote,"

What you need to know:

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events.

 Estimated Distance: 8-9  miles (subject to change) 

Terrain Difficulty: Easy/Moderate  This hike should be  suitable for  beginning hikers who keep fit doing other things. This rating typically describes hikes that are not flat but whose elevation gain is less than 500 feet per mile. For an easy/moderate hike, you should definitely be prepared for some uphill walking. As with all our hikes, expect rocky terrain, broken ground, big tree roots and wet leaves underfoot. .Expect mud - embrace it! 

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold.

Elevation Gain: minimal

Hike Time: About 4 hours. However, this is an estimate. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the pace of the  group. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

Anticipated Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Hike Type:  Loop (actually a series of interconnected loops)

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgement.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" , or who routinely drops out or about whom we have received complaints from fellow Trekkers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared. Bring water (2 liters), hiking boots (not sneakers or trail runners) and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

Please do not talk your cell phone (except for emergencies), listen to the radio or play music during the hike.

This event is a hike; not a guided nature walk or history talk. 

We don't leave the marked trails in pursuit of animals or their tracks. 

We hike in light rain or light snow, but any  extreme weather that renders hiking and/or driving conditions hazardous cancels. 

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

NO DOS and NO GUESTS.  Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Please remember that your Event Organizers  are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:  

Remember: Your Event Organizers  are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at http://www.hikesafe.com/

 You assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you are offering or need a ride, post that on the message board. However, when responding please do so privately by clicking on the person's profile pick and clicking the "message" link.

Please keep your carpooling arrangements private and  off the Message Board. For your safety don't post your phone number on the site.

For more information and a printable trail map, go to: 

http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-central/douglas-state-forest.html


http://www.midstatetrail.org/


We will meet in the parking area next to Wallum Lake near the rest rooms , boat launch and Nature Center (see map). You can access it through the Main Entrance on Wallum Lake Road.

For driving directions go to: http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-central/douglas-state-forest.html
results.name: Mid State Trail Trek through the Douglas State Forest
